top_comment.text:
Am 13.11. ab 20 Uhr könnt Ihr das Eröffnungskonzert live übertragen aus dem 
großen Konzertsaal der Miniatur Elbphilharmonie sehen!

http://www.miniatur-wunderland.de/stream/

On November 13th beginning at 8 pm the great opening concert will be 
broadcast live from the concert hall of the Miniature-Elbphilharmonie. 

http://www.miniatur-wunderland.com/stream/﻿
top_comment.author: Miniatur Wunderland

comments.text:
Ich denke, das Ziel, dass sie eher fertig sind als das Original haben sie 
in jedem Fall eingehalten :)
Das MiWuLa ist wirklich toll, man sollte für einen Besuch aber mindestens 
einen, besser zwei Tage einplanen. Es ist einfach nur gigantisch.
comments.author: Thomas Keller

comments.text:
Die zwei Fachkräfte aus dem Neandertal sind ja mal cool :-)
(der Rest der Philharmonie natürlich auch :)

Mensch ihr habt echt ne tolle Anlage.... Wenn ich mal nach Hamburg komme, 
muss ich euch umbedingt besuchen :)
comments.author: Michael Keller

comments.text:
Ich drücke die Daumen, dass der Stream streamt und dass auch sonst alles so 
gelingt, wie ihr es geplant habt. Good luck!!!
PS.: falls ihr zwischendurch mal eine Aufheiterung braucht:
http://blog.cupofcoffee.de/?p=3391
comments.author: Sascha B. (writeln)

comments.text: Da wurde das Budget bestimmt besser eingehalten...
comments.author: Rainer S.

captions.text: For 12 years now, the largest model railway in the world
can be marvelled at in Hamburg's historic warehouse district.
And for12 years, there's been incessant building, planning, and expanding.
Nowadays, on 1,300 sq m model layout, about 930 trains
run across Central Europe, Scandinavia, and America.
Time and again, important events and buildings in reality
are prompting us to build adaptations and replica
with much love for details.
A little more than a year ago a new idea came up:
The Elbphilharmonie in small.
As part of the HafenCity it was to be located in the Hamburg layout, later on.
On time for the Grand Opening of our little Elbphilharmonie
we'll take a look at the different stages of its development.
On November 14th 2012, Hamburg's culture senator, Prof. Barbara Kisseler
and Elbphilharmonie director Christoph Lieben-Seutter
laid the foundation stone for an elaborate building project.
Ever since, the Elbphilharmonie has been a big subject
for the entire Wunderland team -
next to all other tasks which need to be taken care of.
Especially the challenge of beating the "Big Sister" in getting finished
was a great motivation.
In the first weeks and month hereafter
the team had to figure out which of the manifold ideas
were technically feasible at all, by means of a rough model.
With old structural components many tests were carried out
with the extemporary Elbphilharmonie, for example,
to develop an opening mechanism for the concert hall.
After the first wooden model with correct dimensions was built in spring 2013,
the model makers and electricians spent some time with Gerrit and Frederik
in order to compare the progress of the project with the original vision.
The base scaffold of the HafenCity was taking shape.
But soon, the architects of the small Philharmonie were aspiring for more:
Painstakingly, the roof was shaped manually with mouldable fleece,
then spackled and ground several times in order to create a perfect surface.
Not only was a realistic exterior of upmost importance for the team,
also the interior was supposed to become a convincing replica
of the Elbphilharmonie. For example, the escalators
were designed at the computer.
After they've been milled, single parts were assembled manually.
But they got their final look by applying spray paint and adhesive foil.
Also, there's noticeable progress at the HafenCity.
Just as with the Airport before, all railings in the HafenCity
were specifically designed and fitted.
Piece by piece they're being attached to the quay walls.
The houses in the HafenCity are growing as well.
Also computer designed true to the real-life counterpart,
their single components were milled.
Early summer 2013, our model makers were ready
to outfit the building with details like windows.
The Elbphilharmonie is supposed to open up
in order to grant our visitors a view into the concert hall.
Therefore, the model needs a mechanism which opens up the front
via push-button action.
The electricians had to calculate the right speed and angle,
because the two opening wings have different sizes.
Proper preparatory work led to results which met all requirements.
For the opening mechanism and all lights to illuminate the HafenCity
the electricians had to lay many meters of electric wire underneath the model.
Thus, they can actuate all of the 6,000 LEDs and the push button actions,
and ensure the energy supply.
In a large group meeting, the first light tests
were brought to a close with great enthusiasm.
The small HafenCity is approaching its completion.
The new element is 6 square meters large, all-in-all.
Because there was not enough space for a new area
at the original Hamburg layout, the Wadden Sea had to be removed.
It wasn't always easy, but after some effort we managed to separate it
without substantial damage. Subsequently, the new elements
were carried upstairs for a blocking rehearsal.
Now it would become apparent whether everyone worked with precision,
or whether the foundation panels need further fitting.
But, experience and good calculations led to a precise result.
The months prior to the Grand Opening were used to fill the layout with details.
As always, many humorous and loving insights
into daily life at Hamburg's HafenCity can be found.
In order to give the model the final realistic touch,
a new sheet of water was poured into the entire harbour area within two nights.
The necessary interval of 6-7 hours between pouring
and processing the water material further
led to some very short nights.
One of the most important details in the Elbphilharmonie
is the concert hall, of course.
Meticulously, the entire orchestra ensemble was replicated,
from the correct instruments, down to the hairstyle of the conductor.
In order to give the final scenery some liveliness,
the little figures were equipped with a mechanism
enabling them to move.
But not only the concert hall is supposed to impress with animation:
Our electricians installed light and animation effects
at all corners of the Philharmonie.
The final days of the construction time were filled with important steps.
For the overall finish, specifically the windows were essential.
In order to be very true to the original,
they were milled and coloured individually.
To transport them between our different departments,
we had to be squeamish about naming and labelling them precisely,
so they would be placed at the correct spot at the building.
The work on the roof of the Elbphilharmonie was compartmentalized, as well.
For two days, hundreds of different-sized sequins were glued.
The virtual inner life of the Elbphilharmonie includes,
next to the detailed concert hall,
many apartments and shops which are located everywhere in the building.
Here the ideas of the model makers were boundless - as always.
The moment of truth: It's October 2013 - only 2 weeks prior
to the announced Grand Opening.
At the first placing of the finished Elbphilharmonie onto the layout
we had to make sure that all cables were laid
and the measurements were taken correctly,
and that the weight was calculated precisely.
All problems arising at this moment would have to be eliminaterd
fast and under high pressure.
However, everything fitted exactly and first tests
regarding the new installed electronics ran successfully.
Now, almost exactly one year after the laying of the foundation stone,
our little HafenCity including Elbphilharmonie is completed,
after approximately 13,000 working hours.
With a budget of round-about 350,000 Euro, 22 dedicated employees
have created one of our most beautiful models.
Although the construction work was more elaborate than planned
and caused many sleepless nights, we are now proud to present
the latest addition at the Hamburg layout to our guests.
In a few minutes you can listen to the first concert at our Elbphilharmonie.
Stay tuned for a live stream
of our Grand Opening event and the concert.

title: MiWuLa TV Report: Die Elbphilharmonie und HafenCity
